                  • Chapter 6 Exercise 1

                  Functions of bounded variation

                  6.1

                  Determine which of the following functions are of bounded variation on [0,1].

                  a) f(x)=x2sin⁡(1/x) if x≠0, f(0)=0.

                  b) f(x)=xsin⁡(1/x) if x≠0, f(0)=0.

                  Solution

                  a) When x≠0, we can have f′(x)=2xsin⁡(1/x)−cos⁡(1/x), so |f′(x)|≤3 for x∈(0,1]. It is easy to see that limx→0f(x)=0=f(0), thus f is continuous on [0,1], apply Theorem 6.6, we have f is of bounded variation on [0,1].

                  b) Choose a particular partition

                  P={0,2(2n+1)π,22nπ,…,2π,1}

                  we have

                  ∑k=12n|Δfk|=2π(22n+1+⋯+23)+2π+sin⁡1−2π≥8π(12n+1+⋯+13)≥∑k=1n12n+1≥∑k=1n12n+1

                  Since ∑k=1n12n+1 diverges, we can find N such that ∑k=1N12n+1>M for any M, thus f is not of bounded variation on [0,1].

                  6.2

                  A function f defined on [a,b] is said to satisfy a uniform Lipschitz condition of order α>0 on [a,b] if there exists a constant M>0 such that |f(x)−f(y)|<M|x−y|α for all x,y∈[a,b].

                  a) If f is such a function, show that α>1 implies f is constant on [a,b], whereas α=1 implies f is of bounded variation [a,b].

                  b) Give an example of a function f satisfying a uniform Lipschitz condition of order α<1 on [a,b] such that f is not of bounded variation on [a,b].

                  c) Give an example of a function f which is of bounded variation on [a,b] but which satisfies no uniform Lipschitz condition on [a,b].

                  Solution

                  a) It is easy to see that if α≥1, then f is continuous on [a,b]. For ∀x∈(a,b) and sufficiently small h>0 we have

                  |f(x+h)−f(x)h|<Mhα−1

                  thus if α>1, then f′(x)=0, and f is constant on [a,b]. If α=1, then we have |f′(x)|<M on [a,b], thus f′ is bounded, which means f is of bounded variation [a,b].

                  b) left TO BE DONE

                  c) Define

                  f(x)={x,x∈[a,b)b+1,x=b

                  then f is increasing on [a,b], thus is of bounded variation on [a,b], assume f satisfy some uniform Lipschitz condition, and let α>0 and M>0 be the parameters of uniform Lipschitz condition, we select

                  c=b−1M1/α⟹M|b−c|α=M1M=1

                  but

                  |f(b)−f(c)|=b+1−b+1M1/α=1+1M1/α>1

                  thus we have |f(b)−f(c)|>M|b−c|α, a contradiction.

                  6.3

                  Show that a polynomial f is of bounded variation on every compact interval [a,b]. Describe a method for finding the total variation of f on [a,b] if the zeros of the derivative f′ are known.

                  Solution

                  A polynomial f is continuous on [a,b], and f′ is also a polynomial, thus bounded on [a,b], which means f is of bounded variation.

                  If the zeros of f′ are known, namely {x1,…,xn}, let x0=a and xn+1=b, we may have x1=a or xn=b, but has no effect. By the additivity of total variation we have Vf(a,b)=∑i=1nVf(xi,xi+1). At each interval [xi,xi+1] we can have f being monotonic, since f′ does not change sign, thus Vf(xi,xi+1)=|f(xi+1)−f(xi)|, it follows that

                  Vf(a,b)=∑i=1n|f(xi+1)−f(xi)|

                  6.4

                  A nonempty set S of real-valued functions defined on an interval [a,b] is called a linear space of functions if it has the following two properties:

                  a) If f∈S, then cf∈S for every real number c.

                  b) If f∈S and g∈S, then f+g∈S.

                  Theorem 6.9 shows that the set V of all functions of bounded variation on [a,b] is a linear space. If S is any linear space which contains all monotonic functions on [a,b], prove that V⊆S. This can be described by saying that the functions of bounded variation form the smallest linear space containing all monotonic functions.

                  Proof

                  Let f∈V, then f is of bounded variation on [a,b], thus can be expressed as f=f1−f2, where f1,f2 are monotonic functions on [a,b], thus f1,f2∈S, since S is a linear space, we have f1+(−1)f2=f∈S, this means V⊆S.

                  6.5

                  Let f be a real-valued function defined on [0,1] such that f(0)>0,f(x)≠x for all x, and f(x)≤f(y) whenever x≤y. Let A={x:f(x)>x}. Prove that supA∈A and f(1)>1.

                  Proof

                  That f(0)>0 means 0∈A, so A is nonempty and has a supreme, let a=supA and assume a∉A, then we must have f(a)<a, thus for ε0=a−f(a)>0 we can find b∈A such that b∈(a−ε0,a), so f(b)>b>a−ε0=f(a), on the other hand, from b<a we have f(b)≤f(a), so we have f(b)>f(a)≥f(b), a contradiction.

                  To prove f(1)>1, we only need to prove 1∈A. Assume a=supA<1, then we can have f(x)<x whenever x∈(a,1]. As we have both f(a)>a and 1>a, it is possible to choose some b∈(a,f(a))∩(a,1], for this b we have f(b)<b and b<f(a), so we get f(b)<f(a) and b>a at the same time, a contradiction to f being monotonic increasing. Thus supA=1, and the conclusion follows since we already proved supA∈A.

                  6.6

                  If f is defined everywhere in R1, then f is said to be of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞) if f is of bounded variation on every finite interval and if there exists a positive number M such that Vf(a,b)<M for all compact intervals [a,b]. The total variation of f on (−∞,+∞) is then defined to be the sup of all numbers Vf(a,b),−∞<a<b<+∞, and is denoted by Vf(−∞,+∞). Similar definitions apply to half-open infinite intervals [a,+∞) and (−∞,b].

                  a) State and prove theorems for the infinite interval (−∞,+∞) analogous to Theorem 6.7, 6.9, 6.10, 6.11 and 6.12.

                  b) Show that Theorem 6.5 is true for (−∞,+∞) if "monotonic" is replaced by "bounded and monotonic". State and prove a similar modification of Theorem 6.13.

                  Solution

                  (a) Mark the theorem analogous to Theorem 6.x as Theorem 6.x', and prove:

                  Theorem 6.7': If f is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞), then f is bounded on (−∞,+∞).

                  Proof: We first have Vf(0,0)=|f(0)|<M, for any x∈(−∞,+∞), f is of bounded variation on [x,0] or [0,x], thus Vf(0,x)<M or Vf(x,0)<M, in either case we have

                  |f(x)|<|f(0)|+M<2M

                  thus f is bounded.

                   

                  Theorem 6.9': Assume f and g are each of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞), then so are their sum, difference and product. Also we have

                  Vf±g(−∞,+∞)≤Vf(−∞,+∞)+Vg(−∞,+∞)Vf⋅g(−∞,+∞)≤AVf(−∞,+∞)+BVg(−∞,+∞)

                  where

                  A=sup{|g(x)|:x∈(−∞,+∞)},B=sup{|f(x)|:x∈(−∞,+∞)}

                  Proof: Suppose M1 is the positive number such that Vf(a,b)<M1 for all compact intervals [a,b] and M2 is the positive number such that Vg(a,b)<M2 for all compact intervals [a,b]. From

                  |f(xk)−g(xk)±(f(xk−1)−g(xk−1))|≤|f(xk)−f(xk−1)|+|g(xk)−g(xk−1)|

                  we can see that |Δ(fk±gk)|≤|Δfk|+|Δgk|, thus on every finite interval [a,b] we have Vf±g(a,b)≤Vf(a,b)+Vg(a,b), this means f±g is of bounded variation on every finite interval. Further, we can have Vf±g(a,b)≤M1+M2 for all compact intervals [a,b], so f±g is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞). To prove the inequality, for any −∞<a<b<+∞, we have

                  Vf±g(a,b)≤Vf(a,b)+Vg(a,b)≤Vf(−∞,+∞)+Vg(−∞,+∞)

                  thus Vf(−∞,+∞)+Vg(−∞,+∞) is an upper bound of Vf±g(a,b), and the inequality follows.

                  Similarly, let h=f⋅g and we can have Vh(a,b)≤AVf(a,b)+BVg(a,b) on every finite interval [a,b], thus h is of bounded variation on every finite interval. Further, we can have Vh(a,b)≤AM1+BM2 for all compact intervals [a,b], so h is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞). To prove the inequality, for any −∞<a<b<+∞, we can see the number AVf(−∞,+∞)+BVg(−∞,+∞) is an upper bound of Vh(a,b), and the inequality follows.

                   

                  Theorem 6.10': If f is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞), and |f(x)|≥m>0 for all x, then g=1/f is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞) and Vg(−∞,+∞)≤Vf(−∞,+∞)/m2.

                  Proof: From |Δgk|≤|Δfk|/m2, we see that Vg(a,b)≤Vf(a,b)/m2, thus suppose M1 is the positive number such that Vf(a,b)<M1 for all compact intervals [a,b], we can have Vg(a,b)≤M1/m2 for all compact intervals [a,b], this shows that g is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞). From Vg(a,b)≤Vf(a,b)/m2 we see that Vf(−∞,+∞)/m2 is an upper bound of Vg(a,b) for any −∞<a<b<+∞, and the inequality follows.

                   

                  Theorem 6.11': If f is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞) and c∈R, then f is of bounded variation on (−∞,c] and on [c,+∞), and we have Vf(−∞,+∞)=Vf(−∞,c)+Vf(c,+∞).

                  Proof: Since f is of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞), we can find M such that Vf(a,b)<M for all compact intervals [a,b], thus Vf(a,c)<M for all a<c and Vf(c,b)<M for all b>c, it follows that f is of bounded variation on (−∞,c] and on [c,+∞). Notice that

                  Vf(−∞,c)=sup{Vf(a,c):−∞<a<c}Vf(c,+∞)=sup{Vf(c,b):c<b<+∞}

                  and we have Vf(a,b)=Vf(a,c)+Vf(c,b), thus Vf(a,c)+Vf(c,b)≤Vf(−∞,+∞) for all a,b such that −∞<a<c<b<+∞, it follows that

                  Vf(−∞,c)+Vf(c,+∞)≤Vf(−∞,+∞)

                  From Vf(a,b)=Vf(a,c)+Vf(c,b) we can also get Vf(a,b)≤Vf(−∞,c)+Vf(c,+∞) for all a,b such that −∞<a<b<+∞, it follows that

                  Vf(−∞,+∞)≤Vf(−∞,c)+Vf(c,+∞)

                  and this completes the proof.

                   

                  Theorem 6.12': Let f be of bounded variation on (−∞,+∞). Let V be defined on (−∞,+∞) as follows: V(x)=Vf(−∞,x) if −∞<x<+∞, V(−∞)=0. Then both V and V−f are increasing functions on (−∞,+∞).

                  Proof: For x<y we have Vf(a,y)=Vf(a,x)+Vf(x,y) for all a<x, thus we can have

                  Vf(a,y)≤Vf(−∞,x)+Vf(x,y)⟹Vf(−∞,y)≤Vf(−∞,x)+Vf(x,y)Vf(a,x)≤Vf(−∞,y)−Vf(x,y)⟹Vf(−∞,x)≤Vf(−∞,y)−Vf(x,y)

                  this means Vf(−∞,y)=Vf(−∞,x)+Vf(x,y), so V(y)−V(x)=Vf(x,y)≥0 and V(y)≥V(x), which means V is increasing.

                  Let D(x)=V(x)−f(x) for x∈(−∞,+∞). Then if x<y, we have

                  D(y)−D(x)=Vf(x,y)−[f(y)−f(x)]≥0

                  the last inequality follows from the definition of Vf(x,y). This means D is increasing.

                  6.7

                  Assume that f is of bounded variation on [a,b] and let P={x0,x1,…,xn}∈P[a,b]. As usual, write Δfk=f(xk)−f(xk−1),k=1,2,…,n. Define

                  A(P)={k:Δfk>0},B(P)={k:Δfk<0}

                  The numbers

                  pf(a,b)=sup{∑k∈A(P)Δfk:P∈P[a,b]}

                  and

                  nf(a,b)=sup{∑k∈B(P)|Δfk|:P∈P[a,b]}

                  are called, respectively, the positive and negative variations of f on [a,b]. For each x in (a,b], let V(x)=Vf(a,x),p(x)=pf(a,x),n(x)=nf(a,x) and let V(a)=p(a)=n(a)=0. Show that we have

                  a) V(x)=p(x)+n(x).

                  b) 0≤p(X)≤V(x) and 0≤n(x)≤V(x).

                  c) p and n are increasing on [a,b].

                  d) f(x)=f(a)+p(x)−n(x).

                  e) 2p(x)=V(x)+f(x)−f(a),2n(x)=V(x)−f(x)+f(a).

                  f) Every point of continuity of f is also a point of continuity of p and of n.

                  Solution

                  (a) If x=a, there is nothing to prove. Suppose x∈(a,b], for any partition P∈P[a,x], we let ∑(P) denote the sum ∑|Δfk| corresponding to the partition P, then

                  ∑(P)=∑(A(P))+∑(B(P))≤pf(a,x)+nf(a,x)=p(x)+n(x)

                  thus we can have V(x)≤p(x)+n(x). Conversely, given A(P1) and B(P2) with P1,P2∈P[a,x], we see that add a point to P1 will enlarge A(P1), suppose P1={a=x0,x1,…,xn=x}, and a new point c is added between xk and xk+1, then A(P1) and A(P1∪{c}) differs on Δfk+1=f(xk+1)−f(xk) and f(xk+1)−f(c),f(c)−f(xk), let Δ1=f(k+1)−f(c) and Δ2=f(c)−f(xk), we have Δfk+1=Δ1+Δ2. Split in cases:

                  If all three deltas are positive, they are equal and A(P1)=A(P1∪{c}).

                  If Δfk+1<0, then it does not contribute to A(P1), but Δ1 or Δ2 may be positive, thus A(P1)≤A(P1∪{c}).

                  If Δfk+1>0 but one of Δ1 and Δ2 is negative, suppose Δ1<0 and Δ2>0, then Δ2 contributes to A(P1∪{c}) more than Δfk+1 contributes to A(P1), so A(P1)<A(P1∪{c}).

                  In conclusion we have A(P1)≤A(P1∪{c}) thus A(P1)≤A(P1∪P2). Similarly we can have B(P1)≤B(P1∪P2). Thus

                  ∑(A(P1))+∑(B(P2))≤∑(A(P1∪P2))+∑(B(P1∪P2))=∑(P1∪P2)≤Vf(a,x)=V(x)

                  so we have p(x)+n(x)≤V(x).

                   

                  (b) By definition, p(x)≥0 and n(x)≥0, use (a) we get the result.

                   

                  (c) If a≤x<y≤b, then for any P∈P[a,x], the partition P′=P∪{y}∈P[a,y], thus ∑(A(P))≤∑(A(P′))≤p(y), so p(x)≤p(y) and p is increasing. Similarly for n.

                   

                  (d) We have f(x)−f(a)=∑(A(p))−∑(B(P)) for any P∈P[a,x], thus

                  f(x)−f(a)+∑(B(P))=∑(A(P))≤p(x)⟹∑(B(P))≤p(x)−(f(x)−f(a))⟹n(x)≤p(x)−(f(x)−f(a))⟹f(x)≤f(a)+p(x)−n(x)

                  and

                  ∑(A(P))−(f(x)−f(a))=∑(B(P))≤n(x)⟹∑(A(P))≤n(x)+f(x)−f(a)⟹p(x)≤n(x)+f(x)−f(a)⟹f(x)≥f(a)+p(x)−n(x)

                  (e) Use (a) and (d) we have

                  2p(x)=p(x)+V(x)−n(x)=V(x)+[p(x)−n(x)]=V(x)+f(x)−f(a)2n(x)=n(x)+V(x)−p(x)=V(x)−[p(x)−n(x)]=V(x)−f(x)+f(a)

                  (f) Theorem 6.14 means if c∈[a,b] is a point of continuity of f, then it is also a point of continuity of V. Thus for ∀ε>0, there exists δ>0 such that whenever |x−c|<δ, we have

                  |f(x)−f(c)|<ε,|V(x)−V(c)|<ε

                  thus use (e) we have whenever |x−c|<δ:

                  |p(x)−p(z)|=12|V(x)+f(x)−V(c)−f(c)|≤12(|V(x)−V(c)|+|f(x)−f(c)|)<12(2ε)=ε

                  thus c is a point of continuity of p, similarly we can prove c is a point of continuity of n.
